Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Interference-Aware Cooperation via Structured Codes: Creating an Empirical Cycle

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The classical approach to wireless communication is to isolate communication links by maximizing signal strength and minimizing interference between users. This simple philosophy is supported by a rich theoretical foundation which has inspired powerful coding techniques and protocols that lie at the heart of modern wireless systems. However, these systems have recently become victims of their own success as the rising density and data requirements of wireless devices have led to a surge in interference. Fortunately, an emerging body of work indicates that the phenomenon of interference may in fact represent an untapped opportunity for increasing the spectral and energy efficiency of next-generation wireless systems. Although many interference-aware communication strategies have been proposed in the literature, the promised gains have been mostly limited to the theoretical realm.

The objective of this project is to create practical interference-aware wireless protocols that can operate near the performance predicted by theoretical bounds in terms of throughput, energy efficiency, and reliability. The project is organized into three complementary thrusts that encompass theory, algorithms, and practice. The first thrust investigates lattice-based constellations and low-complexity codes for the compute-and-forward strategy, which enables receivers to decode linear combinations of transmitted codewords. Compute-and-forward can in turn be used as a building block for realizing interference-aware protocols such as physical-layer network coding and multiple-user MIMO (multi-input-uulti-output) systems. The second thrust aims to implement these protocols on a three-node WARP (Wireless Open-Access Research Platform) testbed. A series of carefully designed experiments will be used to compare the performance of interference-aware strategies while accounting for overhead costs. The third thrust leverages the data collected from these experiments to revise channel models to capture key features that impact the performance of interference-aware strategies such as asynchronism and channel fluctuations. These models will be used to revisit the theoretical foundations of interference-aware strategies and tailor them to the channels encountered in practice. This project features several outreach efforts including undergraduate research experiences connected to the WARP testbed and a public repository of training modules and videos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative project was to design and analyze transmission and reception strategies for efficiently transmitting information over wireless relay networks, where one node in the network acts as a relay for other terminals that wish to communicate information with each other. In such networks, if multiple terminals transmit their information at the same time and in the same frequency band, these transmissions interfere with each other. Traditionally, such interference has been viewed as a nuisance and wireless networks are often designed to avoid such interference. Such an approach simplifies the design of networks but results in lower data transmission rates. Recently, sophisticated relaying strategies that harness interference rather than avoid interference have been designed to increase the rate of data transfer between the communicating nodes. One such scheme is called compute-and-forward and uses lattice codes for effectively harnessing interference. Compute-and-forward using lattice codes was known to work only under ideal conditions that may not be true in some practical networks. An important open question at the beginning of this project was whether these strategies would work well even under practical non-ideal conditions.

An important outcome of this project is the design of transmission, relaying and reception strategies that provide good data transfer rates (throughput) even in the presence of some practical constraints. Specifically, (i) we showed that it is possible to design relaying strategies (error-correcting codes) that enable  multiple transmitters to communicate to a relay with different transmission delays in their links, (ii) we designed error correcting codes that work well even when the channel gains between the transmitters and the relay change within the time interval for transmitting one codeword, (iii) we designed novel classes of lattice codes that can be decoded with lower complexity than previous constructions and we showed that these classes of codes have optimal error performance for very long lengths, (iv) we designed lattice codes based on algebraic integers and showed that these could potentially be useful when there is a small amount of feedback from the receiver (or, relay) to the transmitter, and (v) finally, we designed interference-cancellation based protocols for ultra-low latency and high reliability communications such as what is of interest in 5G wireless communications.

We published 11 papers in journals and peer-reviewed conferences based on this work and we gave several invited talks and seminars to disseminate the results from this project. Two graduate students and a post-doctoral researcher were trained as experts in wireless communications and signal processing.
